column7:
@QuincyLarson Actually, due to the number of rooms being reduced, the dradual dissipation would have been a lot slower, due to the people in the rooms which were too active for some people moving to quieter rooms.
Might the forum be better for that? Maybe. But you have to refresh the forum (sometimes) and what you write there it's up for the whole world to see. Here, you have more freedom, because finding organized data in chat rooms is more difficult than finding organized data in a forum.

@sapioit honestly, if people weren't using the room before hand, what would have happened is a short burst of activity, which would have then gradually dissipated over the following weeks, and the rooms would become inactive again.

I know, I read the forum post, and the discussion post reffered in that post, and answered (that I think it should have been all those around 50 rooms which were active the last month. You could have announced on those that unless the traffic in those would increase in the following month, they would be closed. Also, monthly checks could/should be made for those, but works even without those. Or, at least, ask the people what are the rooms they want the most (maybe count the links in the dicussions).

** @/all Please move discussion of this topic to our forum, or to one of the official Free Code Camp chat rooms: http://forum.freecodecamp.com/t/free-code-camp-official-chat-rooms/19390**

I've been working on it. Currently many external resources are being referenced (e.g imgur assets, google analytics, etc) so trying to figure out a good solution. I am keeping my notes here: https://github.com/thelastmile/intranet/tree/master/fcc
any updates on this?
@jpjenkins Short answer, yes.
is it possible to get fcc offline yet?
I was directed here from the wiki
@abhisekp How about you figure it out and tell ME?
@abhisekp Even if I knew that, that's a huge amount of work.  I'm not your dancing monkey
@SaintPeter :(
@abhisekp No

@SaintPeter I want to make FCC available completely offline for a Windows PC. What **ALL** the softwares and documentations and other references do I need to be made available completely offline?
Could you please list each and everything in detail? (here or in wiki?)
@oryangit lol. OK. :+1:
sorry I forgot to mention..
@abhisekp actually I do..
but he is not trying to contribute :(
A true "stand alone" version would be completely self contained

I mean in the sense that it is a self contained application.  You can run a local instance of FCC, but it by no means a "stand alone" version - it requires MongoDB and lots of other stuff to be installed.
yeah! and that's what the guy is trying to do
No, this is the channel for creating a version of the site that is "stand alone"
@SaintPeter isn't this channel for running FCC locally?
@oryangit I may be able to help you in https://gitter.im/FreeCodeCamp/HelpContributors
@SaintPeter  :point_up: [December 20, 2015 3:10 AM](https://gitter.im/FreeCodeCamp/OfflineMode?at=5675cee0f99ceb846ae6c4f2)
Hi all, I'm trying to run the server locally without luck, I read all the doc. when I run gulp I can see the server is running on port 3001 but I get no response.. any idea?
@DDaems k. great :+1:
@abhisekp I resolved it by reseeding the database. Apperently i seeded it partially with a previous installation attempt.
@abhisekp yup, i just registered on my local instance. though maybe thats why they wheren't showing. but there are still no challenges
i mean have you installed mongodb?
@DDaems Did you follow all the instructions about installing mongodb, etc?
Hi all, I managed to install FCC locally now on my windows machine. But none of the challenges are populated, how can i solve this?
how do I install it offline?
@abhisekp babel-node server/server or node server/debug-entry
@abhisekp that’s a good question for Berkeley
When I try to run FCC offline, the gulp watch slows down my PC. Is there any way, I could run the server w/o watching for any changes?
As for documentation, we’re creating our own, simpler versions of the MDN
I bet if we filtered Stack Overflow posts for just JavaScript, that would significantly reduce the size
@alan1001110 Wow - that’s a great idea. I didn’t realize Stack Overflow had public dumps. 7.3G is big, but I don’t think it will be a problem.

I think the Read-Search-Ask method is a key part of how people are able to get through the challenges, and part of the skill of programming.

Read: Offline users will at least need offline access to documentation. (eg: DevDocs.io)

Search: (AKA: looking at Stack Overflow): The Stack Exchange Data Dump is available for download at https://archive.org/details/stackexchange. For offline access, it might be possible to just use the POSTS portion of the stackoverflow.com portion of the data (7.3G, XML). An option might be download it and run a filter to get rid of data that is unlikely to be useful to offline campers (to shrink the size further). Here's the license. Offline attribution requirements differ from internet use. https://ia600500.us.archive.org/22/items/stackexchange/license.txt And the readme: https://ia600500.us.archive.org/22/items/stackexchange/readme.txt

Ask: Ask a friend can be done offline too...
https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/FreeCodeCamp/issues/3855
